item.title: Amazon, Microsoft Cloud Services Face U.K. Probe
item.description: The U.K.’s communications regulator has referred the cloud market to the country’s competition watchdog for an investigation, alleging that certain features by market leaders Amazon and Microsoft could limit competition.

item.title: Dollar's Falls Are Likely To Be Temporary
item.description: The dollar edged lower after Wednesday’s weaker-than-expected ADP employment survey but these falls are unlikely to last and gains for the euro and sterling against the U.S. currency should be temporary, UniCredit Research said.

item.title: German Bunds Find Support But New Highs Likely to Be Tested Again
item.description: It is encouraging that Bunds are finding support around crucial yield levels, but signs of lasting relief aren’t in sight, Commerzbank Research said.

item.title: French Industry Data Slips, Denting Previous Trends
item.description: French industrial output fell 0.3% in August, suggesting a tight monetary environment, following successive interest-rate increases in the eurozone, is weighing on demand.

item.title: Q&A With the Sustainability Chief of Oilfield-Services Firm SLB
item.description: Katharina Beumelburg, CSO of the company formerly known as Schlumberger, discusses an epiphany in Greenland and her belief that engineering and innovation are the answers to climate change.

item.title: Casino Reaches Restructuring Agreement With Creditors
item.description: Casino said it had entered a lock-up agreement with secured creditors related to its financial restructuring.

item.title: Germany's Trade Surplus Falls Less Than Expected
item.description: Germany’s adjusted trade surplus decreased by less than expected to 16.6 billion in August, as both exports and imports declined.

item.title: Nikkei Rises 1.8%, Led by real estate, Auto Stocks
item.description: Japanese shares ended higher, led by gains in real estate, auto and bank stocks, as the U.S. bond-market rout eased, alleviating concerns about higher borrowing costs.

item.title: Pandora Scales Up Investments; Sets New Guidance
item.description: Pandora said it now targets organic growth of 7%-9% from 2023 to 2026 and an EBIT of DKK8.8-9.7 billion by 2026, adding it is increasing investments in brand desirability and the store network.

item.title: Boustead Plantations Stake Sale Fails, But Deal Is Still On
item.description: Boustead Plantations’ shares surged Thursday with a key shareholder stepping in with an offer for the palm-oil producer after another company withdrew from a stake-acquisition deal.

item.title: Where Have the Traders Gone? A $4 Trillion Market Is Stuck in a Rut
item.description: Hong Kong’s stock market has stalled, trading volumes are slumping and foreign investors are backing away.

item.title: America's Food Giants Confront the Ozempic Era
item.description: Nearly 7% of the U.S. population is projected to be on weight-loss drugs in 2035.

item.title: After Crackdown, China Sees New Wave of 'Everyday Feminism'
item.description: With Beijing having snuffed out public advocacy, a growing interest in gender issues can be seen in the popularity of books and podcasts.

item.title: Ukrainian Men Abroad Avoid War, and Are Racked by Guilt
item.description: Thousands of Ukrainians abroad uprooted their lives to join the fight at home. Others opted to watch the conflict from afar and now wrestle with growing hostility and their own guilt.

item.title: Rising Interest Rates Mean Deficits Finally Matter
item.description: Investors ignored deficits when inflation was low. Now they are paying attention and getting worried.

item.title: How Volkswagen Is Leaning Into Americana to Ease Off China Dependence
item.description: The VW Group’s market share in China, where the company sells a third of its cars, is waning as homegrown rivals hit the market. WSJ breaks down how Volkswagen is pivoting away from an overreliance on China by leaning into American tastes.

item.title: The biggest U.S. airlines are searching for thousands of jet-engine parts with fake safety certificates that were installed on their planes during maintenance work.
item.description: The biggest U.S. airlines are searching for thousands of jet-engine parts with fake safety certificates that were installed on their planes during maintenance work.

item.title: A record run of downward revisions to the federal government's monthly jobs report is discouraging some Wall Street traders from making big bets on the data.
item.description: A record run of downward revisions to the federal government’s monthly jobs report is discouraging some Wall Street traders from making big bets on the data.

item.title: U.S. stocks closed higher as the bond-market rout eased, with the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow rising 0.8%, 1.4% and 0.4%, respectively.
item.description: U.S. stocks closed higher as the bond-market rout eased, with the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow rising 0.8%, 1.4% and 0.4%, respectively.

item.title: Ford posted a 7.7% increase in third-quarter unit sales in the U.S., lifted by strong customer demand for its large gas-engine pickup trucks and a surge in hybrid-vehicle sales.
item.description: Ford posted a 7.7% increase in third-quarter unit sales in the U.S., lifted by strong customer demand for its large gas-engine pickup trucks and a surge in hybrid-vehicle sales.
